title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: Very possibly we should have to pay duties upon carrying our Cotton to Northern Ports, but that would be on only one sixth of the whole, while we should introduce the manufactures bought with the other five sixths into Charleston, Savannah, Mobile, and New Orleans at a rate of Duty barely sufficient for Revenue, say ten or fifteen per cent.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: Charleston, 12 May, 1831 Your very obliging, and highly interesting Letter of 17th — 27th Feb., my dear Sir, reached me a short time since, and I avail myself of the first vessel direct from here to Havre to render you an answer by way of acknowledgement.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: His father also was born in St. Croix, but lived in Charleston, South Carolina, where he died in 1826.

title: Correspondence of James Fenimore-Cooper /
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
snippet: People had come there in great numbers from New York, from Philadelphia, from Charleston, and from other parts of the United States.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: * The village of Aboyne is properly " Charleston in Aboyne."

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: We'll up the moor of Charleston,*And o'er the water of Dee,And hine awa' to Candecaill;It's there that we should be.
